title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: And, see here, Chirnside, I was a brute beast to youonce--quarrelled with you years ago--"

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: "Look here, Chirnside," Fenwick went on, "the Little 'Un can't read;but, do you know, she sleeps with my old mother's Bible under herpillow.

title: Life and Correspondence of David Hume, Volume I (of 2)
author: Burton, John Hill
snippet: Dr. Walter Anderson, minister ofChirnside, having caught the fire of literary ambition, made the remarkto Hume, one afternoon when they had been enjoying the hospitalities ofNinewells: "Mr. David, I daresay other people might write books too; butyou clever fellows have taken up all the good subjects.

title: Life and Correspondence of David Hume, Volume I (of 2)
author: Burton, John Hill
snippet: A dowager of an elder generation may have lived forsome time at Ninewells during David Hume's youth, though he does notmention her: or there may have been some collateral member of thefamily, to whom the lines may have been addressed; for, in a series ofextracts which I have obtained from the Kirk Session Records ofChirnside, I find that a David Home _in_ Ninewells, who cannot have beena lineal ancestor of the philosopher, had a numerous family baptizedbetween 1691 and 1701.

title: Life and Correspondence of David Hume, Volume I (of 2)
author: Burton, John Hill
snippet: George Hume, son of the minister of his native parish,Chirnside, who was connected with his own family, followed the humbleoccupation of a baker in the Canongate, and rose to the dignity ofdeacon of his trade.

title: Life and Correspondence of David Hume, Volume I (of 2)
author: Burton, John Hill
snippet: Hewas the second son of Joseph Hume, or Home, proprietor of the estate ofNinewells, in the parish of Chirnside, in Berwickshire.

title: Life and Correspondence of David Hume, Volume I (of 2)

title: Domestic details
